RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
From  1970  to  1996,  Indonesia  successfully  reduced  poverty  incidence  from  more  than 
50% to less than 18%.  However, the 1997–1998 Asian crisis unraveled the progress that had 
been  achieved  and  poverty  incidence  increased  to  more  than  40%  in  1998.  This  led  the 
Government to scale up its efforts to fight poverty, and as a result the number of poor people 
decreased  to  pre-crisis  levels  by  2004.  By  2009,  poverty  incidence  had  decreased  further  to 
14.2%.  Despite  these  gains,  33  million  people  remain  poor,  poverty  incidence  is  substantially 
higher than the national average in many parts of the country, and nearly 50% of the country's 
population is categorized as "near poor," living on less than $2 a day.1  
 
The Government of Indonesia has made poverty reduction a priority in its Medium-Term 
3. 
Development  Plan  (RPJM),  2004–2009,  which  incorporates  key  elements  of  the  National 
Poverty Reduction Strategy (SNPK) and highlights the importance of achieving the Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs). The RPJM targets an increase in economic growth to 7.6% and a 
reduction  in  "open  unemployment"2 to  5.1%  by  2009.    It  also  aims  to  halve  the  percentage  of 
those  below  the  national  poverty  line  to  8.2%  by  2009,  increase  school  enrollment rates  at all 
levels and reduce illiteracy to 5%. Other targets for the 2004–2009 period include an increase in 
life expectancy from 66.2 to 70.6 years, a decline in infant mortality from 35 to 26 per 100,000 
live  births,  and  a  reduction  in  malnutrition  among  children  under  5  from  26%  to  20%.  To 
accelerate poverty reduction, the Government has issued a poverty reduction action plan in line 
with  the  SNPK.  The  action  plan  has  five  focal  areas:  (i)  job  creation  and  poverty  reduction 
programs;  (ii)  macroeconomic  stability  with  stable  prices,  fiscal  sustainability,  and  financial 
sector  reforms;  (iii)  acceleration  of  investment,  exports,  and  tourism  through  reforms  aimed  at 
creating a healthy business climate and flexible markets; (iv) improved access to and quality of 
education  and  health;  and  (v)  infrastructure  development  and  improved  efficiency  of  public 
services, along with expanded private sector participation.  
 
4. 
Indonesia  has  expanded  strongly  since  recovering  from  the  Asian  crisis  and  was  on 
track to meeting many of the RPJM targets before the current economic slowdown. Economic 
growth had accelerated to a 10-year high of 6.3% in 2007 and remained robust at 6.1% in 2008, 
despite  unstable  global  financial  markets  and  a  slowing  world  economy.  However,  economic 
growth decreased to 5.2% year-on-year in the final quarter of 2008 as the global slowdown cut 
into exports and manufacturing. Subdued domestic and external demand is expected to further 
decelerate  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  in  2009.  While  inflation  has  eased  from 
double-digit  rates  and  improved  macroeconomic  management  and  a  stronger  financial  sector 
have  enabled  the  country  to  avoid  the  most  severe  impacts  of  the  current  crisis,  an  overall 
economic slowdown is expected in the short term. It is therefore likely that many of the RPJM 
targets will not be met.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

 
5. 
The  current  global  economic  recession  may  lead  to  additional  strains  on  the  poor  and 
increase  the  vulnerability  of  the  near  poor,  as  economic  growth  stagnates  and  unemployment 
and  underemployment  rise.  Unemployment  is  forecast  to  rise  above  9%  as  layoffs  spread 
domestically  and  more  overseas  workers  lose  their  jobs  and  return  home.  More  people  will 
probably be pushed into the informal sector—which already accounts for about two-thirds of the 
labor force—where wages are low and jobs not secured. Protecting the poor and reducing the 
vulnerability of the population living on less than $2 a day will be a high priority as these groups 
are vulnerable to even small income losses. 
 
B. 
 
Inequity  and  high  levels  of  rural  poverty.  The  SNPK  identified  the  major  causes  of 
6. 
poverty,  including  lack  of  access  to  affordable  quality  food;  lack  of  access  to  quality  health 
services;  lack  of  access  to  quality  education  services;  limited  employment  and  business 
opportunities; lack of access to housing and sanitation services; lack of access to clean water; 
and  lack  of  participation.  All  these  causes  are  related  to  lack  of  access  to  various  forms  of 
capital and infrastructure—human, physical, social, financial, and natural.  
 
7. 
Poverty is particularly high in rural areas, where the majority of the population and more 
than two-thirds of poor people live. Poverty incidence continues to be much higher in rural areas 
(17.4%)  than  in  urban  areas  (10.7%). 3  Disparities  between  and  within  regions  are  also 
significant.  While  the  provinces  with  the  highest  poverty  incidence  rates  are  in  the  outlying 
regions of the country, the provinces in Java and Sumatra tend to have the greatest number of 
poor  people.  In  terms  of  absolute  numbers  of  poor,  Java,  which  has  58%  of  the  Indonesian 
population, accounted  for  55%  of  the  poor  in  2008  (19.2  million  people).  Other  provinces  with 
very  large  number  of  poor  in  2008  were  North  Sumatra  (1.6  million),  Lampung  (1.6  million), 
South  Sumatra  (1.2  million),  South  Sulawesi  (1.1  million),  Aceh  (1.1  million),  East  Nusa 
Tenggara  (1.1  million)  and  West  Nusa  Tenggara  (1.1  million).  These  seven  provinces  alone 
accounted for about 25% of Indonesia’s poor in 2008.4  
 
8. 
Given  such  disparities  across  areas  and  provinces,  national  figures  that  show  solid 
progress toward achieving the MDGs (particularly those related to poverty reduction, education, 
gender equality and child mortality) conceal gaps and an overall level of underdevelopment in 
many  regions.  While  national  figures  show  high  levels  of  access  to  primary  education  for 
children aged 7 to 12, children in rural areas are 20% less likely to enrol and stay in school than 
their  urban  counterparts.  Indonesia's  health  challenges  are  also  great,  with  an  estimated 
582,000 new cases of tuberculosis each year, concentrated in poorer and less developed areas.   
Significant  challenges  in  the  health  sector  are  also  reflected  in  persistently  high  maternal 
mortality ratios: in Indonesia, there are 420 deaths per 100,000 live births, compared with 45 in 
the People's Republic of China, 62 in Malaysia, 110 in Thailand, and 230 in the Philippines.5 
 
9. 
Limited  access  to  service  delivery  and  rural  infrastructure.  For many years before 
the  Asian  crisis,  Indonesia  successfully  used  infrastructure  investments  to  support  poverty 
reduction  and  economic  development.  However,  the  crisis  resulted  in  the  cancellation  or 
infrastructure  projects.  Subsequent

10. 
As  a  result,  infrastructure  and  service  coverage  remains  low  by  regional  standards.  In 
1996, the overall quality of Indonesia's infrastructure exceeded that of the People's Republic of 
China  and Thailand.  However,  today  these  countries  have  overtaken  Indonesia,  which  ranked 
54th  in  a  2007  survey  of  131  countries.7 About  50  million  Indonesians  lack  access  to  treated 
water,  90  million  lack  access  to  electricity,  and  nearly  200  million  are  not  connected  to  a 
sewerage  network.  While  3.5  million  new  customers  were  connected  to  electricity  in  1997,  in 
recent  years  about  1  million  new  customers  have  been  connected  annually,  making 
achievement of the targeted 90% electrification ratio in 2020 unlikely. Indonesia has the lowest 
road  density  in  Southeast  Asia  in  terms  of  length  per  area  or  population,  and  rural  roads  are 
deteriorating because of inadequate maintenance. 
 
11. 
The  availability  of  infrastructure  services  in  rural  areas,  particularly  outside  Java  and 
Bali, is significantly below the national average. About 54% of rural villages are not connected 
by  asphalt  roads  and  more  than  15%  of  all  villages  are  inaccessible  even  by  four-wheel-drive 
vehicles at certain times of the year. Poor roads or no roads mean that government services are 
inaccessible and the high transportation cost in these communities is a major cause of poverty. 
So is lack of water and sanitation: only 15% of rural households have access to drinking water 
from  piped  or  pumped  sources,  and  just  21%  have  septic  tanks  for  disposal  of  human  waste. 
These low levels of access to safe drinking water and adequate sanitation facilities contribute to 
the high incidence of waterborne diseases—diarrhea is the second-largest cause of death and 
stunted  growth  among  young  children.  Access  to  quality  health  and  education  services  is 
particularly limited in rural and remote areas.

South  Sumatra  (53%)  and  Lampung  (54%)  have  low  school  enrollment  rates  for  upper

manage about 30% of total government expenditures.   
 
Despite  early  problems,  there  have  been  significant  gains  from  the  decentralization

process.  Provincial,  district  and  municipal  governments  are  becoming  more  responsive  to  the

responsive  by  integrating  community  aspirations  with  national,  regional  and  sectoral  policies

needs  in  planning  processes,  especially  of  poor  people;  limited  synergy  between  programs  in 
different  sectors;  and  a  disproportionately  high  proportion  of  regional  budgets  allocated  to 
administrative rather than development activities.

remains  one  of  the  key  challenges  of  decentralization.  The  problem  is  most  evident  at  the

Despite  this,  service  delivery  was  generally  thought  to  have  improved  since  decentralization. 
Nearly  two  thirds  of  respondents  identified  improvements  in  public  health  services  and  60%

Community-driven  development  (CDD)  and  government  strategy  for  poverty 
17. 
reduction.  CDD  was  introduced  in  Indonesia  in  1998,  in  the  midst  of  the  Asian  crisis  and 
political upheaval that brought down the Suharto administration and broke down service delivery 
mechanisms. Previously, development processes were largely driven by appointed officials and 
the  central  government.  These  processes  tended  to  exclude  participation,  particularly  by  the 
poor, in setting development priorities, and provided limited accountability for the performance 
of 
responsible  authorities.  Many  poverty-reduction  programs  proved  unstable  and 
unsustainable.  Among  the  reasons for  failure  were  lack  of sufficient  attention  in  the  programs' 
design to the needs of the poor and the lack of local demand and ownership, resulting in service 
delivery that often missed its intended targets. CDD was introduced as an alternative approach 
that  sought  to  institutionalize  Indonesia's  rich  legacy  of  self-help,  community  mobilization  and 
resource pooling for grassroots socioeconomic development.  
 
18. 
The  CDD  approach  gives  communities  control  over  planning  decisions  and  investment 
resources  to  improve  service  delivery.  The  communities  control  the  resources,  and  funds  are 
transferred directly to them, usually to community-managed bank accounts. The community also 
manages project implementation, and generally goes through at least three project cycles, each 
consisting of social preparation, planning, project development, implementation, and operations 
and maintenance. The process is designed to systematically mobilize local people so they can 
prioritize  their  development  needs,  design  activities,  seek  technical  assistance,  manage 
resources,  and  implement  and  sustain  development  actions.  This  organized  and  repeated 
experience in collective action will enable poor villagers to help themselves and to engage local 
governments and national agencies. In the longer term, it is expected that villagers will take a 
more active role in improving the delivery of other pro-poor services (Appendix 2).  
 
19. 
Encouraged  by  the  success  of  CDD  programs  and  following  more  than  a  decade  of 
implementation  experience,  the  Government  formally  adopted  CDD  for  the  Program  Nasional 
Pemberdayaan  Masyarakat  (PNPM)  Mandiri, 15  a  nationwide  poverty  reduction  program 
launched in August 2006. PNPM Mandiri makes a commitment to expand coverage of CDD to 
all 6,408 kecamatans by the end of 2009, and aims to reduce poverty by promoting community 
participation  in  development  planning  and  management,  and  to  deliver  basic  services  and 
infrastructure using the CDD approach. While some of the earlier CDD interventions bypassed 
local governments, PNPM Mandiri seeks to use the CDD approach both to improve local service 
delivery  and  to  promote  local  governance  through  bottom-up  and  pro-poor  planning, 
complementing and furthering the decentralization process (Supplementary Appendix B).

Lessons  learned.  There  is  substantial  evidence  that  CDD  can  be  more  effective  in 
service delivery than other approaches. Independent evaluations of the KDP—the largest CDD 
operation  in  the  world—indicate  an  average  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  more 
than 50%, well above that for other non-CDD rural infrastructure projects implemented in similar 
geographic  areas  of  the  country.  Infrastructure  built  under  CDD  projects  cost  about  40%  less 
than similar works built through other procurement methods, while meeting quality standards.27 
Evidence  also  indicates  that  CDD  is  likely  to  offer  better  cost  recovery  and  operation  and 
maintenance  (O&M)  of  completed  infrastructure  facilities  and  services  because  of  community 
members' strong sense of ownership. CDD also provides better accountability and transparency 
in  decision  making  and  procurement.  Evidence  from  the  RISP  and  other  CDD  projects  shows 
that the direct funds flow mechanism to communities has demonstrably reduced corruption and 
leakage. CDD improves poverty targeting and presents more opportunities for women and the 
poor  to  participate  effectively  in  community  and  local  governance  processes.  World  Bank 
reports indicate that more than 50% of the participants in village decision-making meetings are 
poor and 30–45% are women. About 70% of employment opportunities under CDD are provided 
to poor people.

Benefits and Impacts  

A. 
 
Economic  and  financial  benefits.  Village-level  interventions  will  be  identified  by 
79. 
villagers  through  a  participatory  CDD  process.  It  is  therefore  not  possible  to  conduct 
conventional  ex  ante  economic  and  financial  analysis  of  project  benefits.  However,  impact 
analyses  of  previous  CDD  projects  in  Indonesia  have  demonstrated  that  they  have  a  major 
impact on short-term employment generation and that CDD is highly cost-effective in improving 
community  infrastructure  and  access  to  basic  services.  Previous  projects  have  used  local 
manual  labor  intensively  and  it  has  typically  accounted  for  30–50%  of  civil  works  costs.  The 
Project  is  expected  to  generate  at  least  290,000  person-months  (more  than  24,000  person-
years)  of  short-term  employment  in  the  construction  of  village  investments.  Overall,  PNPM 
Mandiri is expected to generate employment for 24 million people and to increase their incomes 
by  10%–15%.48 As  this  employment  is  largely  provided  in  the  agricultural  off-season,  it  has 
particular benefits for reducing unemployment and vulnerability among the poor.  
 
80. 
The  Project  is  also  expected  to  have  significant  impacts  on  village  economies.  Similar 
types  of  investments  have  been  shown  to  yield  an  average  economic  internal  rate  of  return 
(EIRR)  of  28%–68%.  Economic  benefits  arise  from  opening  access  to  markets  and  lowering 
transport costs in the case of rural roads and bridges, increased incomes, and additional crop 
cycles  from  improved  irrigation,  and  time  saved  in  collecting  water  and  health  benefits  from 
village  water  projects.  Analyses  of  previous  projects  also  show  important  spillover  effects, 
including  stimulating  village  economies,  and  broader  socioeconomic  benefits,  including 
contributing to poverty reduction.

Overall, investments in priority village facilities and services are expected to benefit more 
than  1.5  million  people  in  more  than  300,000  households.  In  addition  to  sustained  village 
participation,  integration  of  the  proposed  Project  within  the  Government's  PNPM  Mandiri 
Program and existing systems will improve the efficiency of management and implementation, 
as well as the magnitude and sustainability of economic and financial benefits compared with a 
stand-alone intervention. The economic analysis is in Supplementary Appendix L.

the  scope  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  is  expected  to  be  insignificant.  Based  on  the 
experience  of  the  PNPM  Mandiri  program,  land  acquisition  may  be  required  for  very  small 
community  facilities.  This  will  not  involve  any  resettlement  of  people,  relocation  of  houses,  or 
significant  impacts  on  productive  land  or  other  productive  assets.  This  is  part  of  the  appraisal 
criteria for community investments. PNPM Mandiri experience indicates that about 500 square 
meters  or  less  per  village  investment  is  usually  required,  affecting  fewer  than  five  households 
(or  25  persons).  Screening  for  potential  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts  is 
incorporated  into  the  community  decision-making  and  planning  processes  and  acquisition  will 
be  financed  by  communities  through  the  block  grants  or  as  community  contributions.  The 
summary land acquisition and resettlement framework is in Appendix 12 and the full framework

88. 
Project  implementation  risks.  The Project will operate in less-developed districts of 
the country where implementation capacities may be limited. To address the risk that this may 
affect project implementation, the Project will strengthen village structures and local government 
councils  and  leadership.  It  will  pay  particular  attention  to  local  government  units  involved  in 
project implementation, including the provincial and district steering committees and the PPIUs 
and DPIUs.  
  
89. 
Institutional  and  governance  risks.  Previous  rural  and  community  development 
projects, including RIS-PNPM, indicate a risk of elite capture. This risk is minimized by several 
features of the project design, including (i) community poverty mapping; (ii) establishment of the 
CIO;  (iii)  election  of  community  representatives  and  village  organizers;  (iv)  representation  of 
women,  minority,  and  marginalized  groups  among  the  community  representatives;  and  
(v)  prioritization  of  the  needs  of  poor  community  members  in  the  village  MTPR  plans.  In 
addition, all civil works will be contracted to the CIOs and will be undertaken primarily through 
manual  labor.  This  will  help  ensure  that  the  jobs  generated  by  the  Project  are  filled  by 
community members. 
  
90. 
Infrastructure projects involving procurement of large amounts of goods and services for 
civil  works  may  be  prone  to  corruption.  To  a  large  extent,  this  will  be  mitigated  through 
community  management  of  the  planning,  oversight,  and  implementation  of  the  civil  works.  In 
addition,  the  existing  financial  management  systems  and  fiduciary  controls  under  PNPM 
Mandiri, which have been developed with assistance from international development agencies, 
are  sound  and  have  adequate  checks  and  balances  to  minimize  corruption  risks.  Finally,  the 
Project’s  complaints  and  problems  handling  unit  will  review  and  address  any  grievances  of 
project  stakeholders  in  relation  to  the  Project,  any  of  the  service  providers,  or  any  person 
responsible for carrying out the Project.  
 
91. 
Targeting risks. Under the current support to RIS-PNPM, some better-off villages have 
been  included  while  some  of  the  poorest  villages  were  not  included.  This  is  likely  because  of 
political  interference  or  inadequate  data  used  for  the  targeting.  This  risk  will  be  mitigated  by 
using 2008 village statistics to verify the project village lists, and involving provincial and district 
governments in reviewing the lists to confirm that the villages included are the poorest.

be  able  to  exercise  administrative  and  technical  supervision  over  the  provincial  project 
implementation units (PPIUs) and district project implementation units (DPIUs).  Accountability 
relationships,  however,  remain  unclear.  Performance  evaluation,  incentives  and  sanctions

proposed.  First,  internal  control  will  be  strengthened  by  providing  adequate  training  to 
community  members  to  enable  them  to  monitor  fund  receipts  and  disbursements  and  to  audit

of  the  work  and  to  verify  the  validity  and  accuracy  of  all  fund  disbursements  (especially  for

that  is  accessible  and  fully  understood  and  trusted  by  the  community  members.  Those  who 
have  complaints  will  have  access  to  a  means  of  making  their  grievance  known.  Third,  the

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Before  the  Asian  crisis  1997–1998,  Indonesia  had  been  successful  in  fighting  poverty.  The  poverty  incidence—the 
proportion  of  the  population  living  below  $1  per  day—was  reduced  from  44%  (1976)  to  11%  (1996).  However,  the 
Asian  crisis  increased  the  poverty  incidence  to  23.6%  in  1998.  With  successful  macroeconomic  management, 
poverty  incidence  steadily  declined  to  14.2%  by  2009,  which  means  that  about  33  million  people  remain  poor.  In 
addition,  about  half  of  the  population  still  live  below  the  $2  per  day  poverty  line.  Disparities  across  regions  are 
striking,  as  provinces  in  outlying  regions  have  poverty  incidence  that  is  well  above  the  national  average.  In  rural 
areas, poverty incidence has been about 8% higher than in urban areas. The current global economic recession is 
also  expected  to  put  additional  strains  on  the  poor  and  near  poor  as  the  employment  opportunities  decrease  and 
economic growth decelerates.  
 
Indonesia’s  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  identified  the  major  causes  of  poverty  as:  (i)  lack  of  access  to  key  social 
services, (ii) absence of economic opportunities, particularly in rural areas, (iii) poor infrastructure in villages, and (iv) 
inadequate  market  linkages.  Weak  governance  hampers  the  progress  made  in  addressing  these  major  causes  of 
poverty. The Medium-Term Development Plan, 2005–2009 focuses on poverty reduction and the achievement of the 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  Its  five  priority  areas  include  (i)  job  creation  and  poverty  reduction 
programs;  (ii)  macroeconomic  stability  with  stable  prices,  fiscal  sustainability,  and  financial  sector  reforms;  (iii) 
accelerating investments, exports, and tourism through reforms for a healthy business climate and flexible markets; 
(iv)  improved  access  to  and  quality  of  education  and  health;  and  (v)  infrastructure  development  by  improving  the 
efficiency of existing services and greater private sector participation.  
 
In  August  2006,  the  Government  launched  the  National  Program  for  Community  Empowerment  (PNPM  Mandiri). 
PNPM  Mandiri  builds  upon  Indonesia’s  accumulated  experience  with  community-driven  development  (CDD) 
programs  and  focuses  on  improving  local  governance  and  service  delivery  at  the  kecamatan  and  village  level  by 
encouraging  participatory  planning  and  providing  block  grants  for  investment  proposals  that  the  communities  have 
developed  themselves.  The  program  will  cover  all  villages  in  the  country  during  2008–2015.  The  PNPM  Mandiri 
promotes  inclusive  community  facilitation  in  planning  and  implementation  of  basic  services  and  infrastructure 
improvements, utilizes simple and transparent funds flow mechanisms, and emphasizes operation and maintenance 
of  completed  works.  The  Project  is  built  into  the  Government’s  PNPM  Mandiri  and  the  project  implementation 
arrangements are aligned with the PNPM Mandiri mechanisms. 
 
The Project is in line with ADB’s country strategy and program for Indonesia, 2006–2009, which includes investments 
in rural infrastructure as strategic key area of engagement to address poverty and regional disparities, and achieve 
the MDGs.

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Findings of Social Analysis  
Indonesia’s infrastructure, particularly in rural areas, remains poor by regional standards. Electrification rates are the 
lowest in Southeast Asia, road congestion is increasing, and the conditions of rural roads are poor. A lack of access 
to infrastructure results in location poverty. People who live in isolated areas with difficult geography and poor market 
links  lack  both  economic  opportunities  and  adequate  levels  of  service  delivery.  More  than  15%  of  all  Indonesian 
villages  are  inaccessible  by  vehicle  all  year  round.  Investments  in  transportation  infrastructure,  agricultural 
infrastructure  (irrigation),  and  education  and  health  facilities  can  significantly  improve  living  conditions  in  remote 
areas, create the basis for economic growth, and improve the welfare of the local population. The positive effect of 
infrastructure on rural welfare has been empirically demonstrated; surveys have revealed that the presence of good 
roads is strongly and significantly correlated with a community’s level of mean income.  
 
Approximately  60%  of  the  population  lives  in  rural  areas  where  agriculture  is  the  main  source  of  livelihood.  One 
reason for low incomes is that ‘farm gate prices’a are very low compared with the price in urban areas for the same 
goods. This is due to the high real transport costs for rural marketable surpluses over poor quality roads. Transport 
costs are even higher for non-motor-vehicle transport where there are no roads. In a rapid assessment of the causes 
of poverty in five of Indonesia’s districts, villagers in isolated areas identified high transport costs to be a major cause 
of poverty. New roads in previously unserved agricultural areas can significantly lower transaction costs and hence 
raise farm gate prices, which will mean higher incomes for people in the agriculture sector, the poorest group of the 
population.  Better  rural  roads  will  also  help  agriculture  extension  workers  reach  rural  farmers  to  provide  technical 
advice and know-how to increase productivity. 
 
Improved access to social services is crucial. Lack of access to quality education significantly decreases productivity, 
employment  opportunities,  and  personal  income.  With  better  roads  and  education  facilities,  teachers  may  be  more 
willing to work in rural schools and the teaching and learning environment would improve, increasing human capital. 
Health and hygiene problems are still major causes of poverty in Indonesia. Through a serious illness or an accident, 
a family can easily lose any accumulated asset. Investments to improve drinking water quality and rehabilitate basic 
health facilities will contribute to increased access to and better quality of health services in rural communities.
